results.byline: By Mike Baker and Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs
results.title: New Details Emerge in University of Idaho Killings: What We Know
results.abstract: The phone log of one victim showed a series of unanswered calls to her longtime boyfriend the night of the attack in Moscow, Idaho, her sister revealed. The police have not identified a suspect.

media.caption: Friends and community members celebrated the victims’ lives during a candlelight vigil in Coeur d’Alene, Idaho, on Wednesday.

results.title: New York Post Takes Aim at Trump, and Hits a Nerve
results.abstract: The paper’s increasingly harsh coverage has gotten the news media and political worlds talking about whether the Murdoch media empire has broken permanently from the former president.

media.caption: Two days after the midterm elections, the paper illustrated former President Donald J. Trump as Trumpty Dumpty about to have a great fall.

results.title: Was This $100 Billion Deal the Worst Merger Ever?
results.abstract: At Time Warner, executives saw AT&T as just a “big phone company from Texas.” At AT&T, they thought Hollywood would play by their rules. That combination led to strategic miscalculation unrivaled in recent corporate history.

results.title: It’s Official: The Leap Second Will Be Retired (a Decade from Now)
results.abstract: On Friday, an international vote was taken to ditch the leap second, a technical fudge that has caused headaches since its inception 50 years ago.
org_facet: International Bureau of Weights and Measures
National Institute of Standards and Technology

media.caption: Clock faces at the Electric Time Company in Medfield, Mass. The leap second was devised as a way to align the atomic time scale, in use since 1967 and derived from the vibration of cesium atoms, with the slightly slower time kept by Earth as it rotates.

results.byline: By Lara Jakes and Marc Santora
results.title: How Was Russia Able to Launch Its Biggest Aerial Attack on Ukraine?
results.abstract: Western and Ukrainian officials have said Moscow’s stockpile of missiles was dwindling. But the assaults this week raise questions about that.

media.caption: A residential building in Kyiv that was hit by a missile on Tuesday. The attack that day, one of the broadest since the Russian invasion began, caused blasts in at least six regions of Ukraine.
